name_origin.etymology: The name provided is modern descriptive Hebrew rather than a traditional Judeo-Arabic term, reflecting the dish's status as a contemporary adaptation. 'Ktzi'tzot' (patties) derives from the Hebrew root K-Tz-Tz (ק-צ-ץ), meaning 'to chop' or 'cut off.' The culinary inspiration, 'Chraime' (or Hraime), comes from the Arabic root 'ḥ-r-m' (forbidden/hot), specifically the diminutive form in Libyan and Tunisian Arabic meaning 'the little hot/spicy one,' referring to the piquant paprika and garlic sauce.
name_origin.sources_notes: While the name is Modern Hebrew, the dish mimics the flavor profile of 'Chraime' or 'Hraime,' a quintessential North African Jewish Shabbat dish. In Djerba, fish balls might traditionally be called 'Keftas' (Arabic) or 'Boulettes' (French).

alternative_names.name: Keftas de poisson (Végétalien)
alternative_names.notes: Francophone North African term for fish balls, modified for the vegan version

alternative_names.name: Hraime
alternative_names.notes: The name of the traditional sauce/dish this recipe emulates

similar_dishes.name: Chraime / Hraime
similar_dishes.similarity: The source material; fish cooked in a spicy sauce of paprika, cayenne, garlic, and caraway.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses real white fish (grouper or sea bass) instead of tofu/wakame.

similar_dishes.name: Sardine Kefta Tagine (Kouari)
similar_dishes.similarity: Balls of minced fish (sardines) cooked in a spicy tomato sauce (chermoula base).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses fatty fish (sardines) and often includes animal fat; not vegan.

similar_dishes.name: Kboukeb
similar_dishes.similarity: Fish stew with tomato, garlic, and cumin/caraway.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Usually uses whole fish steaks or pieces rather than ground patties; includes potatoes.
